we had discussion at a technical level and then up the hiq through carper some concerns were expressed by some member states but the council

considered that the recommendation should be adopted we recognised that there has been a lot of improvement in the situation but that it is not yet stable and that the conditions for prolonging the controls remain

therefore the recommendation was adopted allowing controls for another three months however should be noted that the recommendation also encourages the member states concerned to consider alternative measures pest such as police checks before resorting to the maintenance the prolongation of their internal border controls

the recommendation also maintains the requirement for monthly reports to be submitted by the member states consent and the recommendation itself also acknowledges the improvements that have been made so it does acknowledge the progress and the developments since the previous recommendation
clearly the objective for all remains to return to a normally functioning schengen area as soon as possible however basically the decision is that this is not yet possible right now

the recommendation does require that an assessment is carried out us to whether those controls are needed at all of these points and with the same intensity so where there is no need for them or where they can be carried out with less intensity then they should be but

it is a pleasure to welcome you to this public hearing on prison system and a condition in the european union on behalf of mr klodomorash who as asked me to represent a him this afternoon

present condition are an important element of the justice system of member states and in the european area of freedom of security and justice they play an important role to promote mutual trust among the member states efficient judicial cooperation in the eu and to proper functioning of mutalarecognision tools

in the criminal law area it is essential to ensure that satisfactory detention conditions exist in all member states based on the respect of fundamental rights standards the european parliament as in previous resolution express is concerns about a prison condition in some member states

the libe committee is currently drafting an own initiative report on the subject with the ame of identifying short coming and propose initiatives at a political or administrative level to improve the situation in the european union
the rapporteur in charge of this rapport is a miss juile berger on and i am happy to welcome her year today and give your the floor for a introductory remarks please you have the floor

mmadammmadammr president i would like to thank you for being here at this hearing which i believe will be very interesting a make a contribution to this report on the state of prisons in europe i was particularly keen that the various speakers
should be involved in a specific role in prisons so we will hear representatives of the council of europe members of the council for penal cooperation responsible for detention conditions mr jem

mr an ilinataneva who is a jurist from the french section of the international observatory of prisons who will talk about the conditions of detention of vulnerable people who mariketinil we have a researcher in criminology specialising in minology in

management of prisons i think it is key to hear those various voices and approaches to prisons people from academia from associations from prisons
who will give us an overview the state of prisoners in europe is a huge subject because it relates to detainees and conditions their rights to health their right to see their families right to

vote and so on also relates to reinsertion issues which are key issues staff working in prisons that is also a very important issue and i want to include that in the report as i am drafting the report

i want to focus specifically on the competences of european law and conditions in prisons we are not going to be focusing on thing that has to do with member state competences i have no intention to change anything there and i have no competence to do so might
the aim is to change the basic view that citizens have of prisons detainees are human beings they should not be treated as rejects from society there is a wide variety of
penitentury systems in europe but often we find the same problems over crowding lack of staff violence high rates of suicide old facilities

and france is very poor in this area in relation to its neighbours or in comparison to its neighbours it seems to me that nor than northern european countries a like sweden for example have much better prison conditions they could be a model for us
i expect to be travelling to those countries i am expecting to go to finland with mshultelles help and to sweden and the last point

i have decided not to focus on radicalisation there is a report on that but i think that prisons themselves are a broad enough subject for us to set that aside and focus on respect for the rights of people who are in prison and i now give the floor to our speakers and in fact the chair

and specifically under the heading of the council of europe and respect for fundamental rights of offenders and conditions of detention there we are so just while or our presentation is coming up as far as i am concerned i am the director of the irish privation service

and for the past year i have been the chair of the council for penological cooperation of the council of europe and we will say a little bit more about that but ms taniva and myself are going to share the presentation time alternating between as so ill hand over to elena now

mr president thank you for the invitation to speak in front of the european parliament and i really very much appreciate this briefing that is really comprehensive and very well drafted and to take the talk of

all the existing instruments the case law of the court and really the major issues that currently at stake regarding prison conditions and treatment of prisoners regarding the council of europe on conditions work in prisons has been on the agenda since the sixties already and currently the situation as we see we have

standards at thing work we have monitoring mechanisms and we also have cooperation and assistance activities from the picture in front of view which means that from the standard stating point of view of course the political body s the committee of ministers which adopts

in the case of prisons we do not have a binding legal instruments we have recommendations committee mettingses recommendations so there is a political agreement and commitment to do something but it is not a binding legal instrument and most of you should know the european prison rules the most known text and this text elaborated by the council for pynological cooperation at the level of

of experts in the different fields and then they go to the steering committee which is the european committee on crime problems and afterwards the committee of ministers of dob this text what is interesting and very important in this cases that there is a synergy between the standards setting and and the monitoring mechanisms the court of human rights despite the fact that we do not have binding legal instruments

refers to the recommendations of the committee of ministers as the only existing standards and by doing so upgrade them to a quasi binding text for the country in question for which the judgment is delivered then you have the committee for the prevention of torture which also develop standards the standards of the cpt itself and also refers to the standards of the community of ministers

you have also the commissioner for human rights you have the parliamentary assembly which has monitoring mechanisms and the committee ad ministers itself which also is controlling how the countries are implementing the decisions of the court then this work of the monitoring bodies

come back on revising of different rules take place and we are currently going to revise the european prison rules commentary for the time being so we have also the cooperation and sistance activities and here is the role of the european union as well because a lot of these activities with eastern european countries and turkey are founded by the european union joint programmes with the council of europe so we are working together in this practical field of implementation

the council of panological cooperation itself was created the e thousand nine hundred and eighty as an advisory body to the european committee on crime problems but as of two thousand and eleven it is now an intergovernmental committee with the working group which composed of nine elected members so they are elected in their personal capacity like our chair

so that they can express more independently their views without being dependent on the policy of their country of origin and one year there is a plenary meeting so we meet in the form of all the forty seven member states and that is how the information the networking exists at this level

mr president the major legal standards that have been developed by the council of europe through the pccp include the following although there are and much wider range but for todays discussion the european prison rules developed in two thousand and six

european rules for community sanctions and measures which have just recently been revised and we expect will be approved and adopted in the next couple of months european prevention rules from two thousand and ten european rules for juveniloffanders from two thousand and eleven and

perhaps we felt it was worthwhile posing a question that we might come back to later on is at time now for a binding european prisons charter and this was an initiative that was previously developed around two thousand and four an initiative of the european parliament and the parliamentary assembly of the council of europe for various reasons

that did not progress at the time but perhaps that is something practical and tangible that we could return to now as far as the pccp is concerned regarding current tasks which is on the next slide we are developing a document of guidelines or standards on children of imprisoned parents of whom there are a couple of million across the european area

as a lena mentioned were working on revising the european prison rules commentary also developing updating the recommendation on penal mediation or victim of ender mediation and perhaps that will end up as a wider document on restartative justice

the group also organises every year the conference of directors of prisons and provtion services and that is really much more than a conference per say it is also an opportunity once a year when all the directors of prisons and probation services across the forty seven member states can come together and

that opportunity is used as a vehicle for the development of work that is ongoing in the pccp it anyone time and also the promulgation and dissemination of the latest find recommendations or guidelines

alina will come back shortly to talk about the space statistics on the prison and provation population across the council of europe area which is extremely important and i think there are significant opportunities there in relation to the development of practice and standards based on facts and statistics that that can emerge

and one of the documents we completed are tool that we completed last year but are still very much of relevance all across europe and its its various bodies relate to radicalisation to violent extremism particularly within the prison populations but also more widely in the community and especially in the prevation population
you see here just very few slights from the latest council of europe statistics penal statistics they are collected since thirty years already

and since out fifteen years collected also statistics on community sanctions and measures or non costolio sanctions and measures the later statistics which concern two thousand and fifteen because we collect it one year afterwards in order to be able to collect until the end of the previous calendar year and to analyse all the data show that

still thirty three of the forty seven member states are facing prisonovercroding and what is more alarming is that twelve countries are facing overcrowding in the course of several years already and the situation is not changing countries in eastern europe have reduced a lot their prison population which remains the highest numbers of to compare to general population
but overcraweding is something which exists in both eastern and western part of europe and this is very alarming the situation is not changing despite a lot of efforts that are made to improve

the work of the judiciary the use of community sanctions and measures than on the next slay to can see the foreigners we can see that there are a number of countries which face problems with the rising number of foreigners in prison and of those foreigners
twenty six of only european citizens european union citizens so a lot of countries that countries not members of the european union and citizens are in european prisons and the situation is

small serious at pritrile level were about more than one third of the prisoners are foreigners in rich or prisons you can see i dot know what it is very visible the countries which face most serious numbers of foreigners in prison then on the next slight you see the costs of imprisonment the cost of imprisonment also very high eur twenty one million

which is quite high it is based on the real expenditures and not on the fhrecine budgets so the average for europe is und one hundred years prisoner per day and there are huge differences of course between the countries because of the gross national product so these are only few numbers that show you the

the space statistic spactatistics both for prison and for community sanctions and measures are really a very serious exercise with a lot of validation a lot of a lot of data which needs to be analysed and we are now having a joint project with the european union there is

to do a research on pretrial detention and on foreigners which is currently taking place and we are going to have meetings of the national correspondents in order to chick certain methodology of collection of data and comparison of data so we hope that this exercise will improve even further the high quality of data

mr president finally on the next slit we have listed some of the challenges that are faced in this area and very very often i believe in this field of work particularly as regards prisons there can be a big focus on physical structures building more prisons bigger prisons better prisons

and i believe that very often the challenges in this area are not some much about physical structures although physical structures are important but more about the invisible ones the invisible structures such as culture commitment and cooperation

and similarly the values that we either have or want to develop within our prisons and privation systems how we develop and manage our our people and encourage cooperation within organisations and across organisations prisons in provation remain forgotten and an ignored area of public attention very often and as a result can attractive very low level of political priority

equally across the european area there are very different different legal systems legal and cultural traditions and so on that that have a bearing the economic situation particularly over the last few years for many countries has been a huge challenge

resulting in the down running and delapidation of buildings reduced staffing and so forth political pressures have already mentioned and among the public fear of crime and the the perception to respond in a more punitive way very often and sometimes are often a lack of interagency cooperation at local national and

european level and the last point i want to make is to return to the one i mentioned earlier on about the idea of perhaps this being the time to move to develop a binding european prisons charter which might not only have benefits for prisoners but also the people working within prisons and indeed wider society mr president

mr president there were certainly a lot of questions asked and as the chair has pointed out a lot of very profound one so i i am going to just focus on on a few as ms mikola from romania pointed out

i am conscious that the history and the culture on the context of every country has a bearing on where their penal policy is now on what direction it can go and each individual member state and jurisdiction needs to be

conscious of that and equally the point that she made about that the prison conditions in any country can have a profound effect on issues like radicalisation to violent extremism and that is something that we in the pccp have pointed out in our guidelines and handbook documents on on radicalisation

the member from spain raised a number of very interesting points and questions un certainly the one about mental health which can can be very negatively impacted by poor prison conditions and even the experience of imprisonment itself

is really significant i am conscious in in my own country in ireland a very high percentage of people in prison have mental health issues mental illness and we have been trying to address that in a number of ways including through an early diversion programme for people who are remanded in custody having said that we as i am sure other member states experience have a long way to go
in how we respond to people with mental health issues because it is such a significant one ciplfrofrom germany also focused in some of our questions on prison overcrowding and asked was that linked

at least in part or otherwise to a lack of alternatives and in my view the contributors to prison overcrowding can be many and varied complex and i want to remind the audience that the council of europe last year completed a document on on prison overcrowding a white paper on prison overcrowding which recognises the various

and the extent of the root causes of prison overcrowding from the stage of people being remanded in custody right through to the length of prison sentence the overuse of short sentences the lack of alternatives and so on and highlight some ways that prison overcrowding can be addressed and i am part of a working group as as my colleague mr taneva is that is working to try and progress

the findings of of that white paper how optimistic she ask as well are the panel to see improvements in the penal system i always operate in my own job in ireland and within what we do in the council of europe from the point of view that we have to be in the business of hope and while the balance can be very fine it can be tilt it either way particularly in the negative way very easily

by a whole lot of things i see a lot happening across europe to show that positive change is possible and for example in my own country a few years ago we had a high of around four seven hundred people in prison

which was at an overcrouded level and that has been reduced by around twenty now to three six hundred and three seven hundred that was done through a whole variety of measures the better implementation of alternatives early release programmes more extensive supervision for those people on early release

substitution of community service for fines which is still still coming in and the point i want to make is that as it states in the white paper the causes of overcrowding our complex and equally the response that is needed has to match the complexity and i think italy for example is one of the countries that among others that have made significant

strives and developments through that approach of identifying what is causing overcrowding and then having targeted measures on a coordinated basis to deal with that and finally the chair raised the question of the maintenance of relationships between prisoners and their children

as i said also earlier on that is one of the tasks that the pccp has on its current work programme and the council of europe at all levels are extremely exercised and energised about that and have urged us in the pccp to progress that particular issue in suffer as we can drob guidelines or a recommendation as fast as we can because it does affect
such a huge number of completely innocent people who are serving a sentence but in another way are serving that sentence

judiciary local communities public opinion media everybody is concerned and this is very important so the eu as parliamentarians also have a very important role to play because you are the link with the public opinion with population and with the politicians

and you should convey what is important than it is in the wide paper in prison overcrowding there should be a national strategy long term strategy you cannot do just a measure here a measure there but you really have to think for the future and alternatives use

without strategy may bring are the result broadening of criminal justice network which is very dangerous so you can have more people in prison and more people in addition with alternative sanctions and measures so a strategy is needed to multi agency cooperation and dialogue is needed constantly
